OK so systems biology.
Has been around for a few years now, but it's still seen as at the leading edge of biological modeling and biology, so actually a very large proportion.
For instance of biological funding in the UK, has been directed towards this area of systems biology and it involves a form of cycle which is really very.
Familiar to to us from science in general, which is to do with.
Obtaining data from experiments.
Building models using that data model construction, then analyzing those data, analyzing those models.
This is typically a human occupation.

To analyze these models, human beings will then get some biological insight out of those, so they'll understand something of the biology that they didn't, hopefully before, which they will hopefully will be publishable.
This will again lead to new revisions of hypothesis, which once more, because these are hypothetical beliefs, then lead to the choice of experiments and the cycle goes round.
So what's different about systems biology from the traditional scientific cycle is the attempt to use computation in some parts of the cycle OK to actually help the scientists with this activity.
In our subproject we've tried to go to the extreme, which is to see if one could replace human effort in as many of these different parts of the cycle as possible.
OK, so that we can actually give the maximum amount of support to the scientists.
Not with the intention of making all scientists redundant, but rather of making them more capable of dealing with mountains of data.
